head.title: 2 Men Fired Upon by Needlelike Objects

hedline.hl1: 2 Men Fired Upon by Needlelike Objects

abstract.p: Two men are struck by needlelike objects fired by group of men in car in separate incidents on Manhattan's West Side (S)

block.p: Two men were struck early yesterday by what the police described as needlelike objects fired by a group of men in a car in two incidents on the West Side.
Neither man was seriously hurt in the incidents, which occurred about five minutes apart, and the police were unsure how the objects were fired, said a police spokesman, Sgt. Brian Burke.
Two men were struck early yesterday by what the police described as needlelike objects fired by a group of men in a car in two incidents on the West Side.
Neither man was seriously hurt in the incidents, which occurred about five minutes apart, and the police were unsure how the objects were fired, said a police spokesman, Sgt. Brian Burke.

In the first incident, at 4:45 a.m. at 10th Avenue and West 52nd Street, Emanuel Linijak, 29, was hit in the arm. In the second, at 4:50 a.m. in front of 454 West 45th Street, Robert Brito, 32, was hit in the back, Sergeant Burke said.

Mr. Linijak was treated at St. Clare's Hospital and released. Mr. Brito refused medical attention. Both men told the police that they thought the object that struck them came from inside a green or gray four-door Honda. Neither victim could provide a license plate number for the car.
In Mr. Linijak's case, a needle two and a half inches long was recovered as evidence. In the second incident, no needle or dart was recovered, the police said.
Both victims told the police that there were three men in the car, whom they described as white or light-skinned Hispanics in their 20's.
